title: Is MasterChef Australia the best of all MasterChefs? - Quora

response.answer_text: That’s quite a subjective question, which really amounts to a survey. But I’ll answer it because I just finished watching the first season of MasterChef Canada, and I was pondering how I felt about it. And I won’t be watching any more seasons. So far I’ve watched the first seasons of the Australian, UK (revival), US, and now the Canadian franchise as well as the first season of the junior shows of the US and Australia. The Aussies are light years beyond the rest of them IMO, though the junior US show is also much better than its adult counterpart (imagine Gordon Ramsey without swearing and temper tantrums). I don’t usually watch reality shows because I don’t think there is much ”reality” featured; instead we get cheap drama, and I am sorry, but no matter how much other people seem to like that (better to watch other people’s lives fall apart than dealing with your own problems?), I just can’t stand it. There is still too much drama for me even in the Australian show, contestants are too easily “gutted” by a setback, every tear is milked, stupid questions about “how does it feel” to lose are all too frequent, and the writing for the presenter’s lines is overwrought — we’re talking about a cooking show, not life and death — but overall the tone of the show has won me over. I like how the contestants behave with each other. There’s no cut-throat “anything to win”. You can’t fake most of the camaraderie. I also like how the judges treat the contestants. Reality shows often fall entirely short on respect, and here there is a lot of it. The judges are clearly decent people, and they seem to actually care about the contestants and their journey and passion for cooking, and are interested in helping them succeed. We get small glimpses of the life in the MasterChef residence (nothing intrusive), and of the judges having dinner with the contestants, and it’s all quite convivial. That atmosphere is a solid departure from what’s normal for reality shows, and I appreciate it. I like seeing people grow through a difficult experience. The Australian show also has hugely more episodes (70 or so compared with 15 for the Canadians), and consequently we get much more familiar with the strengths and weaknesses of the contestants, and come to know them better. The Australian show, because it goes easy on the drama, features a lot more cooking. We also get master classes where two of the judges themselves (the ones who are actual chefs; the third is a food critic) cook their own takes on the various challenges the contestants faced during the week. Recipes are given (also published on the Network Ten site), and one can follow them easily. The chefs give lots of little tips, and often show how a contestant’s dish could have been improved — it’s very instructive and a bit of a relief from the competition. In addition, there are opportunities for winning contestants to get short master classes from famous Australian chefs. In short, the experience of watching it is pleasant and educational, and it’s easier for me to sympathize with the contestants and their tribulations. I’ll continue watching the additional Australian seasons while I‘ll not bother with the others, except the junior US show. Maybe most telling is that after the other shows I didn’t feel like cooking anything, while the Australian show had me buy decent pots (no, not the ones used on the show) and venture a bit further ahead in my own sad, culinary trials. EDIT: I’m now almost at the end of the 3rd season, and I no longer recommend it, except for the master class episodes. What had begun to irk me already has become worse, what I liked has diminished, and it’s now clear that this show, too, is way too staged and edited and dramatized, and that by no means “the best” amateur cooks get promoted — the judges (more likely the producers) obviously favoured certain people. I’m also wondering how much of the camaraderie (and the free-flowing tears) come about because the contestants are people in what really amounts to a hostage situation — sequestered in a house, not allowed to talk to their loved ones except for a 10-min phone call once a week. WTF! Had I known this beforehand I would have probably never bothered to watch it at all. I won’t even finish watching this one; it’s all too mawkish and artificial.

I think it’s difficult to answer such a question. What has to be remembered is that the Masterchef franchise is audience centric and the format is changed to suit the 40 or so countries that produce a Masterchef programme. What may appear to be a great version in one country, may have little or no appeal to the audience in another country. When the original Masterchef programme was developed in the UK back in 1990, it was a pure cookery competition. There were no big prizes, very little in the way of back stories - just cooking and being judged for the food that was created. Today, the UK version still, very much, follows the original format because that’s how British audiences like it. When the franchise went global, reality TV productions had started to take off. So, foreign producers decided to adapt the format by incorporating a higher level of production-induced drama and tension into the programme. That’s what their audiences wanted, so that’s what they were given. Today, versions such as the Australian and American productions have escalated the cookery competition concept into something that is now pure reality TV that focuses more on drama, conflict and, in the case of the US version, even abuse and bitchiness among the contestants. The awarding of a big cash prize and book publishing deals adds an extra layer of hard-nosed competitiveness to the programme. As a result, many of the international versions tend to make cooking a secondary consideration, preferring instead to create a programme where the audience can witness conflict, sad back stories, back-stabbing and all the stuff that reality TV fans thrive on. All enhanced by judicious editing and dramatic music that often drowns out what’s actually going on in the competition. So, the Australian version is obviously going to be the best version for Australians and the US version is clearly the best for US audiences - they’ve been designed and produced with their respective audience and commercial ratings in mind. Ultimately, the whole franchise has been a huge success for it’s UK creators and has become one of the most popular cookery competitions world wide and whilst UK audiences do get the opportunity of seeing foreign versions on subscription channels, the audience that enjoys those tense, reality TV versions is a completely different audience that tunes into the original version screened by the BBC.
